23 Neighborhoods Covered

Best Neighborhoods for Expats in Argentina

Find your perfect barrio across Buenos Aires, Mendoza, and Córdoba. Updated 2026 rent prices, safety rankings, and honest assessments from expats who live here.

Safety Reality: Palermo, Recoleta & Belgrano Are Very Safe

Despite media sensationalism, these neighborhoods have crime rates comparable to European cities. The main risks are petty theft (phone snatching), not violent crime. Most expats never experience any issues.

Quick Comparison

Best Overall
Palermo Soho
Perfect balance of amenities, transport, and expat community
Safest
Recoleta
Lowest crime rates, well-lit streets, embassy security
Best Value
Villa Crespo
Palermo vibes at 40% lower rent
Best for Families
Belgrano
Quiet streets, good schools, family-friendly
Best Nightlife
Palermo Hollywood
Bars, clubs, and restaurants open until dawn
Most Authentic
San Telmo
Historic cobblestones, tango, Sunday market
Hottest Food Scene
Chacarita
BA's fastest-growing restaurant district
Best Green Spaces
Palermo Botánico
Botanical Garden, Japanese Garden at your doorstep
Budget Pick
Almagro
Lowest central rents, authentic porteño life
15 Neighborhoods

Buenos Aires

Argentina's capital and the most popular expat destination. World-class dining, vibrant culture, and neighborhoods for every lifestyle and budget.

Palermo Soho
Palermo Viejo
10/10
HighVery GoodExcellent

The undisputed expat capital of Buenos Aires — cobblestone streets lined with designer boutiques, artisan coffee shops, and some of the city's best restaurants. If you want to be in the center of expat life, this is ground zero.

Average Rent:
$1,400–$2,400/month
Best For:
Digital nomadsYoung professionalsFirst-time expatsFoodies
Highlights
  • + Best restaurant density in Buenos Aires
  • + Plaza Serrano weekend craft fair
  • + Walking distance to Bosques de Palermo
  • + Strong expat community and networking
Considerations
  • - Highest rents in the city (doubled since 2023)
  • - Can feel like an expat bubble
  • - Noisy on weekends, especially near Plaza Serrano
  • - Restaurants price for foreign wallets
Read full guide
Palermo Hollywood
8/10
HighGoodVery Good

The nightlife and entertainment hub of Buenos Aires, packed with bars, clubs, and TV production studios. More lively and edgy than Soho, with slightly lower rents and a younger crowd.

Average Rent:
$1,200–$2,000/month
Best For:
Night owlsYoung professionalsCreativesSocial butterflies
Highlights
  • + Best nightlife in Buenos Aires
  • + Craft beer and cocktail scene
  • + Film and TV production culture
  • + Great street food options
Considerations
  • - Very noisy on weekends (Thu-Sun)
  • - Street-facing apartments can be loud
  • - Some blocks feel sketchy late at night
  • - Less family-friendly vibe
Read full guide
Recoleta
9/10
HighExcellentExcellent

Buenos Aires' most elegant neighborhood — French architecture, embassy-lined streets, and the safest area in the city. The choice for families, retirees, and anyone seeking upscale living with European sophistication.

Average Rent:
$1,200–$2,200/month
Best For:
FamiliesRetireesSafety-conscious expatsCulture loversLong-term residents
Highlights
  • + Safest neighborhood in Buenos Aires
  • + Beautiful French architecture
  • + World-class museums (MALBA, Bellas Artes)
  • + Large apartments with classic details
Considerations
  • - High rent prices
  • - Can feel stuffy or overly formal
  • - Limited nightlife scene
  • - More conservative atmosphere
Read full guide
Belgrano
Belgrano R / Belgrano C
8/10
Mid-RangeVery GoodVery Good

The quiet, family-friendly neighborhood where long-term expats settle. Tree-lined streets, good schools, the city's Chinatown, and a residential calm that's hard to find elsewhere in BA.

Average Rent:
$900–$1,500/month
Best For:
Families with childrenLong-term residentsQuiet livingAsian food lovers
Highlights
  • + Best schools in Buenos Aires
  • + Chinatown (Barrio Chino) food scene
  • + Quiet, tree-lined residential streets
  • + Lower rents than Palermo/Recoleta
Considerations
  • - Further from city center
  • - Quieter social/nightlife scene
  • - Fewer coworking options
  • - Can feel suburban for some
Read full guide
San Telmo
7/10
Mid-RangeModerateGood

The soul of old Buenos Aires — cobblestone streets, tango bars, antique shops, and the legendary Sunday market. Authentic, bohemian, and more affordable than northern neighborhoods.

Average Rent:
$700–$1,100/month
Best For:
Artists and creativesBudget-conscious expatsHistory loversTango enthusiasts
Highlights
  • + Sunday market (Feria de San Telmo)
  • + Authentic tango culture and milongas
  • + Historic architecture and cobblestone streets
  • + Most affordable central neighborhood
Considerations
  • - Side streets can be unsafe at night
  • - Older buildings with potential maintenance issues
  • - Tourist-targeted scams near the market
  • - Less modern infrastructure
Read full guide
Villa Crespo
8/10
Mid-RangeGoodVery Good

The smart money move — Palermo vibes at 40% lower rent. An up-and-coming neighborhood with an excellent food scene, outlet shopping, and genuine Argentine character.

Average Rent:
$600–$1,000/month
Best For:
Value-seeking expatsFoodiesLong-term residentsYoung professionals
Highlights
  • + 40% cheaper than neighboring Palermo
  • + Rapidly improving food and cafe scene
  • + Excellent Subte B connectivity
  • + Outlet shopping on Avenida Córdoba
Considerations
  • - Still gentrifying — some rough blocks
  • - Fewer parks and green spaces
  • - Less polished than Palermo
  • - Street quality varies block to block
Read full guide
Núñez
7/10
Mid-RangeVery GoodGood

A hidden gem at the northern tip of Buenos Aires — quiet, safe, and affordable by northern BA standards. Home to River Plate stadium and a growing expat community seeking space and tranquility.

Average Rent:
$700–$1,200/month
Best For:
FamiliesRemote workers wanting spaceSports enthusiastsBudget-conscious in safe area
Highlights
  • + Spacious apartments at lower prices
  • + Costanera Norte waterfront access
  • + Very safe residential area
  • + River Plate stadium atmosphere on game days
Considerations
  • - 35-45 min Subte to center
  • - Limited dining options
  • - Quieter social scene
  • - Can feel isolated from main expat hubs
Read full guide
Almagro
6/10
BudgetGoodExcellent

The authentic Buenos Aires experience at budget prices. Almagro is where porteños actually live — traditional pizzerias, tango clubs, and a real neighborhood feel far from the tourist circuit.

Average Rent:
$500–$850/month
Best For:
Budget-conscious expatsSpanish learnersTango enthusiastsLong-term residents
Highlights
  • + Lowest rents in central Buenos Aires
  • + Authentic milongas and tango culture
  • + Excellent Subte connectivity (2 lines)
  • + Real porteño neighborhood experience
Considerations
  • - Less visually appealing than northern neighborhoods
  • - Some blocks feel rough
  • - Very few expats — you'll need Spanish
  • - Limited international food options
Read full guide
Caballito
6/10
BudgetGoodExcellent

The geographic center of Buenos Aires and a solidly middle-class neighborhood. Great transport, affordable rents, and a genuine Argentine family feel. The unsexy but practical choice.

Average Rent:
$500–$900/month
Best For:
Long-term budget expatsFamiliesSpanish immersionThose wanting genuine BA
Highlights
  • + Geographic center of Buenos Aires
  • + Lowest rents in well-connected areas
  • + Parque Rivadavia weekend book fair
  • + Excellent Subte A connectivity
Considerations
  • - No trendy food/cafe scene
  • - Very few other expats
  • - Can feel unglamorous
  • - Limited nightlife options
Read full guide
Puerto Madero
6/10
Ultra PremiumExcellentModerate

Buenos Aires' newest and most luxurious neighborhood — modern skyscrapers, waterfront promenades, and the highest safety in the city. A bubble of modernity that feels like a different country.

Average Rent:
$2,500–$4,500/month
Best For:
Corporate expatsHigh-income professionalsSafety-first familiesJoggers and cyclists
Highlights
  • + Safest neighborhood (private security throughout)
  • + Modern luxury apartments with amenities
  • + Reserva Ecológica for nature walks
  • + Waterfront dining and sunset views
Considerations
  • - Most expensive rents in Buenos Aires
  • - Feels sterile and lacks character
  • - No Subte line — poor public transport
  • - Empty and quiet on weekends
Read full guide
Colegiales
7/10
Mid-RangeVery GoodGood

Palermo's quieter, more residential neighbor. A hidden gem with tree-lined streets, a growing cafe scene, and the feel of a small town within the city. Perfect for expats who want proximity without the noise.

Average Rent:
$800–$1,300/month
Best For:
CouplesRemote workersQuiet-seeking Palermo refugeesDog owners
Highlights
  • + Quieter alternative to Palermo
  • + Growing cafe and restaurant scene
  • + Small-town feel within the city
  • + Walkable to Palermo Hollywood
Considerations
  • - Limited Subte access (relies on buses/trains)
  • - Smaller restaurant selection
  • - Very few other expats
  • - Some blocks near train tracks are noisy
Read full guide
Chacarita
7/10
Mid-RangeGoodVery Good

The fastest-gentrifying neighborhood in Buenos Aires. Former working-class barrio now home to BA's hottest new restaurants, natural wine bars, and creative studios. The 'next Palermo' is happening right now.

Average Rent:
$600–$1,100/month
Best For:
FoodiesEarly adoptersCreative professionalsValue seekers
Highlights
  • + Hottest restaurant scene in Buenos Aires
  • + Natural wine bars and specialty coffee
  • + 30-40% cheaper than Palermo
  • + Authentic neighborhood character
Considerations
  • - Still rough around the edges
  • - Safety varies block by block
  • - Limited green spaces
  • - Gentrification displacing original residents
Read full guide
Palermo Botánico
Palermo Chico (nearby)
9/10
HighVery GoodExcellent

The quietest corner of Palermo — centered around the Botanical Garden and Japanese Garden. All the benefits of the Palermo location with a fraction of the noise.

Average Rent:
$1,200–$2,000/month
Best For:
CouplesNature loversQuiet-seeking professionalsFamilies
Highlights
  • + Botanical Garden and Japanese Garden at your doorstep
  • + Quieter than Palermo Soho
  • + Excellent Subte D connectivity (Plaza Italia)
  • + Walking distance to both Palermo and Recoleta
Considerations
  • - High rents (comparable to Soho)
  • - Limited dining options in the immediate area
  • - Tourist traffic around the gardens on weekends
Read full guide
Barrio Norte
7/10
Mid-RangeVery GoodExcellent

A central, well-connected area straddling the border of Recoleta and Retiro. Classic Buenos Aires apartments, excellent transport, and a convenient location for everything.

Average Rent:
$800–$1,400/month
Best For:
ProfessionalsCentral location seekersClassic apartment loversFirst-time expats
Highlights
  • + Best public transport connectivity in BA
  • + Central location — walk to everything
  • + Classic apartments with high ceilings
  • + Dense shopping and services
Considerations
  • - Avenida Santa Fe is very busy and noisy
  • - Commercial character lacks neighborhood charm
  • - Limited green spaces
  • - Can feel impersonal
Read full guide
La Boca
4/10
BudgetCautionModerate

The colorful birthplace of tango and home of Boca Juniors. Iconic for tourists but a complex choice for residents — vibrant culture with significant safety considerations.

Average Rent:
$400–$700/month
Best For:
Adventurous expatsFootball (soccer) fansArt loversUltra-budget travelers
Highlights
  • + Lowest rents in Buenos Aires
  • + Iconic cultural heritage (tango, art)
  • + La Bombonera stadium experience
  • + Authentic working-class character
Considerations
  • - Higher crime rates — serious safety concerns
  • - No Subte access
  • - Tourist traps around Caminito
  • - Infrastructure challenges (flooding)
Read full guide
4 Neighborhoods

Mendoza

Argentina's wine capital at the foot of the Andes. Sun-drenched, affordable, and perfect for expats seeking a slower pace with world-class wine at their doorstep.

Centro Mendoza
Centro / Mendoza Downtown
7/10
BudgetGoodModerate

The commercial heart of Argentina's wine capital — a walkable grid of plazas, sidewalk cafes, and affordable living. A compact, sunny city center where everything is within reach on foot.

Average Rent:
$400–$700/month
Best For:
Budget-conscious expatsWine loversSpanish learnersRemote workers seeking sun
Highlights
  • + Walkable city grid with 5 connected plazas
  • + 300+ days of sunshine per year
  • + Rents 50-60% cheaper than Buenos Aires
  • + World-class wineries within 30 min drive
Considerations
  • - Extreme summer heat (35°C+ in January)
  • - Limited public transport (no subway)
  • - Smaller expat community than BA
  • - Less nightlife variety than Buenos Aires
Read full guide
Godoy Cruz
7/10
BudgetGoodGood

Mendoza's vibrant adjacent suburb — a favorite among young professionals for its nightlife strip on Arístides Villanueva, craft beer scene, and lower rents just minutes from downtown.

Average Rent:
$350–$600/month
Best For:
Young professionalsNightlife loversBudget expatsCraft beer fans
Highlights
  • + Arístides Villanueva nightlife and dining strip
  • + Lowest rents in greater Mendoza
  • + Metrotranvía connection to Centro
  • + Growing craft beer and wine bar scene
Considerations
  • - Noise on and near Arístides on weekends
  • - Less polished than Centro
  • - Some blocks feel more suburban
  • - Limited English spoken
Read full guide
Chacras de Coria
Chacras
8/10
Mid-RangeVery GoodLimited

A charming wine country village 20 minutes from downtown Mendoza — tree-lined streets, bodegas within walking distance, and the largest concentration of expats in the region. The 'Palermo' of Mendoza.

Average Rent:
$500–$900/month
Best For:
Wine enthusiastsCouplesRetireesNature loversExpat community seekers
Highlights
  • + Bodegas and vineyards within walking/cycling distance
  • + Established expat community
  • + Saturday artisan market in the village center
  • + Excellent restaurants in wine estate settings
Considerations
  • - Car or bicycle strongly recommended
  • - Limited public transport to Mendoza city
  • - Very quiet — not for those wanting city energy
  • - Fewer daily services than city center
Read full guide
Guaymallén
5/10
BudgetModerateModerate

Mendoza's most affordable residential zone — a sprawling suburb east of downtown with growing commercial areas, good value apartments, and a genuine local feel far from the tourist trail.

Average Rent:
$250–$450/month
Best For:
Ultra-budget expatsLong-term residentsSpanish immersionFamilies seeking affordable space
Highlights
  • + Most affordable rents in Greater Mendoza
  • + Metrotranvía connection to Centro
  • + Palmares Open Mall for shopping
  • + Authentic local neighborhood experience
Considerations
  • - Less visually appealing than central areas
  • - Car recommended for outer areas
  • - Safety varies by block — research carefully
  • - Very few expats or English speakers
Read full guide
4 Neighborhoods

Córdoba

Argentina's second city and university hub. Young energy, rich history, and the most affordable urban living in the country.

Nueva Córdoba
7/10
BudgetGoodGood

Argentina's ultimate student quarter — a dense, walkable neighborhood packed with bars, cafes, and young energy. The most vibrant barrio outside Buenos Aires, with nightlife that rivals the capital.

Average Rent:
$350–$650/month
Best For:
Young expatsStudentsNight owlsBudget travelersSocial butterflies
Highlights
  • + Most vibrant nightlife outside Buenos Aires
  • + Ultra-walkable dense grid
  • + Rents 60-70% cheaper than Palermo
  • + Parque Sarmiento green space
Considerations
  • - Very loud on weekends (Thu-Sun)
  • - Extremely young demographic (avg age early 20s)
  • - Some petty theft — watch belongings
  • - Fewer professional networking opportunities than BA
Read full guide
Güemes
7/10
BudgetGoodGood

Córdoba's hipster barrio — craft markets, vintage shops, design studios, and a young creative crowd. The Palermo Soho of the interior, with its own distinct character and far lower prices.

Average Rent:
$300–$550/month
Best For:
CreativesDesign loversMarket enthusiastsBudget-conscious foodiesYoung expats
Highlights
  • + Feria de Güemes weekend market — one of Argentina's best
  • + Independent design shops and galleries
  • + Characterful renovated houses and apartments
  • + Excellent artisanal food scene
Considerations
  • - Weekend market crowds can be overwhelming
  • - Older infrastructure — plumbing and electrical can be unreliable
  • - Some blocks feel rough around the edges
  • - Limited parking for car owners
Read full guide
Centro Córdoba
Centro / Casco Histórico
6/10
BudgetModerateExcellent

The historic core of Argentina's second-largest city — home to the Jesuit Block (UNESCO), the cathedral, and a dense commercial center. Affordable, well-connected, and steeped in 400 years of history.

Average Rent:
$300–$500/month
Best For:
Budget expatsHistory buffsThose wanting central convenienceShort-term visitors
Highlights
  • + UNESCO Jesuit Block — 400 years of history
  • + Best transport connectivity in Córdoba
  • + Most affordable central rents
  • + Walking distance to everything
Considerations
  • - Noisy and crowded during business hours
  • - Quiet to the point of emptiness on weekends
  • - Some safety concerns at night on quiet streets
  • - Commercial character — not residential feeling
Read full guide
Cerro de las Rosas
Cerro
7/10
Mid-RangeVery GoodModerate

Córdoba's upscale residential neighborhood — tree-lined streets, excellent restaurants, and a quiet, family-friendly atmosphere. The Recoleta of the interior, with a fraction of the price tag.

Average Rent:
$450–$800/month
Best For:
FamiliesRetireesSafety-conscious expatsRestaurant loversLong-term residents
Highlights
  • + Safest neighborhood in Córdoba
  • + Excellent restaurant strip on Rafael Núñez
  • + Quiet tree-lined residential streets
  • + Houses with gardens — rare in Argentine cities
Considerations
  • - 20 min drive to city center
  • - Car or taxi recommended
  • - Higher rents than other Córdoba areas
  • - Limited public transport
Read full guide

Tips for Choosing Your Neighborhood

Consider Transport Links

Buenos Aires has excellent public transport, but some neighborhoods are better connected than others. Palermo, Recoleta, and Belgrano have multiple subway lines. San Telmo and La Boca rely more on buses.

Budget for USD Rent

Most landlords now quote rent in USD. Rents have doubled since 2023. Factor in security deposit (usually 1-2 months) and potential guarantee (garantía) requirements. Budget-friendly options like Villa Crespo and Almagro offer great value.

Visit Before Committing

Each neighborhood has a very different feel. If possible, spend a few days in different areas before signing a lease. What's charming during the day might be noisy at night. Thursday-Saturday nights are the real test.

Think About Lifestyle

Want cafes and restaurants? Palermo Soho or Chacarita. Prefer quiet evenings? Belgrano or Núñez. Want authentic Buenos Aires? San Telmo or Almagro. Need the safest option? Recoleta.
